China https://www.economist.com/china/ China - Made with love by RSSHub(https://github.com/DIYgod/RSSHub) RS集线器i@diygod.me (DIYgod) zh-cn 2023 年 6 月 30 日星期五 16:12:52 GMT 120 Why China is so keen to salvage shipwrecks in the South China Sea

在南海深处，阳光照射不到的地方，蕴藏着宝藏。去年，中国研究人员在水下约 1,500 米处发现了两艘腐烂的沉船，两艘沉船相距 20 公里。其中一个藏有数千个瓷杯和花瓶，明亮的青花釉半覆盖着淤泥。另一个持有木材。这两艘沉船让人们得以一睹明朝（1368-1644）时期的全球贸易，当时中国南方御窑烧制的瓷器被运往远至欧洲的买家。这些木材可能运往另一个方向，可能运往中国造船厂。然而，这些发现不仅仅引起学者的兴趣。

北京官员表示，这些沉船“证实了中国祖先开发、利用南海以及往返南海的历史事实”。这听起来可能不像地缘政治声明，但此类声明是中国推动控制几乎整个水域的软性一面。这片海域比地中海还要大，但仍然是重要的贸易路线，也是宝贵的鱼类资源和能源储备的所在地。七个国家对其部分地区拥有主权。但中国的范围是迄今为止最广泛的。它的地图上有一条“九段线”，从海岸线延伸超过 700 海里。中国对境内广大地区宣示主权（见地图）。

这项任务大部分落在了中国海军和海岸警卫队的肩上，它们长期以来一直试图欺凌其海上邻国。但中国官员也在整理一个（相当可疑的）历史案例。他们指出中国古代地图和文字中提到了南海。沉船事件为他们的论点增添了另一层内容。按照中国的逻辑，中国旧船的残骸标志着该国曾经控制的领土——因此，它仍然应该控制。

打捞者在南中国海可以找到很多东西。其中靠近南沙群岛的一部分，由于其岩石、礁石和浅滩的绘制不清晰，被称为“危险地带”。沉没的财富的梦想吸引了商业寻宝者。 1985 年，英国人迈克·哈切尔 (Mike Hatcher) 率领一支探险队发现了“格尔德马尔森”号 (Geldermalsen)的残骸，这是一艘 18 世纪荷兰东印度公司的船只，船上载有中国瓷器和黄金。这批“南京货物”在阿姆斯特丹拍卖会上筹集了超过 2000 万美元。

两名中国瓷器专家被派去拍卖会购买其中一些物品，中国认为这些物品是其财产。然而，他们手里只有3万美元，却空手而去。一年后，中国国家博物馆创建了一个水下考古中心，国家开始在该领域进行大力投资。

如今，中国在沉船搜寻领域占据主导地位。在越南也声称拥有主权的西沙群岛附近，中国研究人员发现了至少十艘沉船——他们说，这证明中国几个世纪以来“持续管理”了该地区。很方便的是，中国人似乎在他们声称拥有主权的水域中只发现了他们自己的沉船残骸。他们不与外国考古学家合作，也不容忍其他探险活动。 2012年，一艘中国船只在黄岩岛附近驱逐了一名与菲律宾国家博物馆合作的法国考古学家带领的一艘船。中国、台湾和菲律宾均声称对该地区拥有主权。中国指责探险队试图销毁中国发现该地区的证据。

多年来，中国考古学家一直呆在阳光照射的浅水区，那里更容易发现沉船，潜水员也可以帮助挖掘。不过，自 2018 年以来，他们还一直在深海（200 米以下的任何地方）进行研究，那里的光线较少，压力增加，意味着需要更好的技术。声纳脉冲用于探测海底。潜艇检查有前景的地点。明代的发现表明了中国深入探索的能力。

中国在水下考古方面的进步令人印象深刻。 2007年，它把一艘有800年历史的船“南海一号” （最初由英国团队于1987年发现）打捞出海，放入陆地上定制的盐水箱中。发现明代沉船的研究潜艇名为“深海勇士”号，可容纳三人，可承受深达 4,500 米的压力。它有两个机械臂，可以拾取精致的文物，还有一组摄像头，可以让研究人员创建沉船的数字模型。它的制造商、国有的中国船舶重工集团公司（ CSIC ）宣称，该潜艇95%的零部件都是在中国制造的。

中船重工也制造军舰并非巧合。中国在水下考古领域所做的大部分工作都有军事和战略用途。对南海的详尽调查有助于中国海军在该海域航行。美国前海军军官、现供职于美国智库传统基金会的布伦特·萨德勒 (Brent Sadler) 表示，依赖声纳的船只，例如海军潜艇，会使用收集到的有关海洋温度、洋流、盐度和海底的信息。 2021年，一艘美国核动力潜艇坠入南海海底海脊。

深海专业知识还帮助中国将其他宝藏带上水面。 “神海永石”助力南海大型油气田开发。它已被用来在海底勘探有价值的矿物，如钴、铜、锰和镍。这有助于解释为什么中国想要控制水域，以及为什么它强行阻碍其他国家捕鱼和勘探碳氢化合物和矿物的努力。中国无视海牙法庭 2016 年做出的裁决，该裁决驳回了其大部分领土主张。

然而，专家表示，中国的历史案例就像打捞出来的瓷器一样脆弱。仅仅因为一艘船运载货物往返中国，并不意味着它正在标记中国统治下的领土。九段线似乎出现于 20 世纪 40 年代，对于明朝皇帝来说，它毫无意义，更不用说商人了。南海海底的数千艘船只中，有许多甚至不是中国的。上海纽约大学的谭森·森表示，其中一些为个人和私营公司所有。他们的船员可能来自印度洋彼岸，讲阿拉伯语、波斯语或马来语。

换句话说，南海拥有丰富的多元文化历史。中国最有能力探索这一领域。该地区没有人能够比得上其在深海寻找和挖掘船只的能力。森表示：“从学术角度来看，他们正在做一件非常重要的事情，因为其他人做不到。”但最有能力揭示海洋迷人过去的国家也最有可能歪曲它。 。 ■

; Thu, 29 Jun 2023 14:38:41 GMT /内容/gr5k2isvmtag42su20rqg413u610glqd https://www.economist.com/china/2023/06/29/why-china-is-so-keen-to-salvage-shipwrecks-in-the-south-china-sea How China sees Yevgeny Prigozhin’s mutiny

中国领导人可以从俄罗斯最近上演的瓦格纳戏剧中汲取哪些教训？听北京学者说，中国不是需要教训的国家。相反，俄罗斯应该学习中国的好榜样。具体来说，弗拉基米尔·普京应该学习中国共产党创始人的智慧，他们从革命初期就对武装战士实行严格的、自上而下的政治控制。他们引用毛泽东主席的名言：“党指挥枪，决不能让枪指挥党。”

这种自满的语气可能会让西方一些人感到惊讶。从逻辑上讲，俄罗斯的动荡应该会在中国权力走廊中引发一场自我怀疑的危机。毕竟，就在普京入侵乌克兰的前几天，俄罗斯领导人与中国国家主席习近平签署了一份书面协议，表示“无限”的友谊。尽管俄罗斯军队和雇佣军在乌克兰犯下暴行，但中国的外交官和宣传人员仍坚持一个不变的剧本：即战争是西方的错，西方通过扩大北约联盟将俄罗斯逼入绝境，并且正在因为美国军火商的利益而提供的武器。尽管这些亲俄言论损害了中国在许多西方国家首都（尤其是欧洲）的形象，但他们仍坚持这些观点。

习近平无视所有谴责入侵的呼声，亲自支持普京。三月份对莫斯科进行国事访问时，中国领导人在克里姆林宫门口停了下来，允许摄像机记录下他称普京为“亲爱的朋友”，然后告诉他：“现在发生了一些变化，我们还没有发生过这样的变化。” 100 年来，我们应该共同推动这些变革。”

如今，习近平对普京的赌注看起来比以前更加危险。然而，如果外界期望听到中国领导人公开为支持失败者而烦恼，那么他们就无法理解两国领导人关系的本质。中国和俄罗斯的统治者因蔑视西方及其自由民主准则而强有力地团结在一起。他们的言论揭示了一个共同的信念，即一个古老的、更加黯淡的世界秩序——建立在平衡各个国家利益的基础上，并特别尊重大国——正在卷土重来。每个国家都为这场斗争带来了截然不同的工具和技术。在中国，官员和学者半公开地一致认为，俄罗斯可能是一个鲁莽、有时令人担忧的朋友。但他们也称这场争夺主导地位的斗争是一场漫长的斗争。重要的是西方最终应该被赶出全球舞台中心。

过去几天，审查机构和宣传负责人允许中国公众收到有关瓦格纳集团叛变的相对未经过滤的报道。尽管官方媒体发表了谨慎的报道，称这场危机是俄罗斯的内政，但在线新闻媒体和评论员却没有那么谨慎。审查员允许他们转发雇佣军组织创始人叶夫根尼·普里戈任（Yevgeny Prigozhin）的视频声明并进行辩论，指控俄罗斯最高指挥部存在腐败行为。网民将他比作中国古代的各种叛逆者（人们普遍选择安禄山，一位八世纪的奸诈将军）。如果普京的困境继续下去，这种相对开放的态度可能表明中国给了自己回旋余地。最简单的是，这似乎表明北京高层并不恐慌。

现任清华大学国际安全与战略研究中心的中国人民解放军退役大校周波表示，最近发生的事件应该会增强中国的信心。他回忆起毛泽东在红军还是一群乌合之众游击队时如何向红军强加了党支部和政委，并赞扬现代解放军保持了这一“优良”传统。 “也许俄罗斯发生的事情只是向中国领导层证明我们所做的事情是正确的，”周先生说。他认为，俄罗斯适合利用雇佣军向海外投射力量，否则瓦格纳集团就会早日受到控制，就像美国适合利用伊拉克黑水公司或英国东印度公司等公司的武装承包商来建立一个帝国一样。与营利性军队。但这种外包在中国是绝对不会被容忍的。他说，解放军也不会像瓦格纳集团那样从监狱中招募囚犯，“无论多么勇敢”。

解放军前非洲之角国际反海盗巡逻联络官周先生承认，中国确实使用私营保安公司来保护在海外工作的国民。但他补充道，这是因为“一带一路”倡议这一庞大的基础设施计划将中国企业带到了危险的地方。

好朋友，不同的商业模式

中国并不反对利用平民执行模糊的、准军事任务。大型钢壳船上的渔民有时被称为国家支持的“海上民兵”，以欺凌中国的邻国。但伦敦国王学院的亚历山德罗·阿杜诺 (Alessandro Arduino) 表示，在向海外投射力量时，中国通常更倾向于秩序。他是即将出版的新书《金钱制造混乱：雇佣兵、私人军事公司、无人机和战争的未来》的作者。大约有20家中国私营保安公司活跃在海外。他报告说，除了保护在非洲和其他地方的中国公司和投资之外，他们还经常成为中国高科技人口控制的“品牌大使”，销售面部识别摄像头、无人机和其他监控设备。许多中国警卫手无寸铁，根据需要雇佣带枪的当地人。相比之下，瓦格纳集团等俄罗斯私营军事公司则积极从混乱和杀戮中获利。 “不安全感是他们的商业模式，”阿杜诺先生谈到俄罗斯人时说道。

那么，痴迷于稳定的中国可能听起来不太可能支持普京在乌克兰鲁莽、凶残的冒险。但中国的目标比这场冲突更大。如果战争持续下去，如果最后发现西方疲倦、分裂和衰弱（正如中国仍然希望发生的那样），北京的党领导人将原谅俄罗斯在此过程中的一些混乱。与此同时，解放军指挥官可以期待关于对习近平绝对忠诚的新讲座。 ■

; Thu, 29 Jun 2023 14:38:41 GMT /内容/35cqfoh34dvnh1ubd54u92ihqk792iit https://www.economist.com/china/2023/06/29/how-china-sees-yevgeny-prigozhins-mutiny To understand Xi Jinping, it helps to be steeped in the classics

取四个汉字，都是日常使用的。把它们按一定的顺序排列起来，瞧，它们就变成了一个看起来像古文的短语——古代文人使用的语言。他们所传达的思想可以用普通话来表达，但古典风格却很庄重。这是中国领导人习近平喜爱的一句话，所以所有人都必须效仿。

与任何前任相比，习近平更喜欢引用古典文学作品，尤其是诗歌和哲学来为自己的讲话增添趣味。这符合他所宣称的使命之一：灌输“文化自信”（以及对政治制度的信心）。这有助于提升他的形象。在中国历史上，统治者被认为是博学的。已经出版了两卷，对习近平的经典警句进行了解释。

习近平的这四个字并不是他的古典主义中最丰富多彩的。这是“国之大者” ，他用这个词来表示“国家的主要事务”或“国家的优先事项”。与他随处可见的其他短语不同，它没有明显的起源于众所周知的文本。这就好像一位西方领导人在提出一个伟大的想法时，要编造一个拉丁术语来描述它。习近平这句话的宏大性使其引人注目，这显然是他想要的。

自从习近平在 2020 年访问陕西省期间首次公开使用“国之大折”以来，该词已风靡全国。官员们的讲话中也充满了这样的内容。有关它的文章不断出现在官方媒体上（该短语通常带有引人注目的引号）。中国学者就该主题撰写论文。共产党员在会议上讨论这个词。催生了一个图书产业：“什么是国之大者？”去年出版的一本著作的标题，在 156 页中提供了答案。

为什么这样一个听起来平庸的短语会得到如此多的关注呢？因为习近平所说的“国之大者”是一个包罗万象的词，真正的意思是“我的远大目标”。这个词适用于从“粮食安全”（见下一个故事）到“政治安全”（保持党的执政）和实现“中国梦”（使中国成为世界强国并与台湾统一）等方方面面。习近平表示，官员必须时刻“珍惜国之大者”。这是提醒他们谁是老板的一种方式。当他们使用这个词时，通常会与其他表达对习近平的忠诚的短语结合在一起。

中国的专家试图证明“国之大则”与古典经典有联系，即使它不是与一位文学巨匠相关的短语。上海财经大学的陈成扎就是这样一位学者。他提到了《道德经》，这是两千年前写成的道教哲学的核心文本（习近平喜欢引用它）。这部玄妙之书说宇宙有四件大事（“国之大者”可译为“国家的大事”）。其中之一就是统治者。奉承之意显而易见。

工程图像

中国的一些愤世嫉俗者怀疑习近平是否真的像他所表现的那样博学。他的大部分教育都被动荡的文化大革命打乱了。他就读于中国最负盛名的大学之一清华大学，当时那里除了马克思主义和毛泽东主义之外几乎没有教授任何东西，古典文学也受到蔑视。表面上看，习近平的学位是化学工程学位。后来，在担任省领导期间，他获得了清华大学的博士学位。他的论文英文题目是“中国农村市场化的尝试性研究”。

官方媒体上并没有出现这样的怀疑。 1969年，十几岁的习近平被下放到农村干农活，据说他拖着“装满书的沉重行李箱”。他收集的古典文献表明他对从孔子到 11 世纪诗人苏轼等众多作家的熟悉程度。据说他读过许多莎士比亚的作品，至少公众是这么听说的。官方通讯社新华社将他的阅读清单描述为“不断增加”。也许令人惊讶的是，他还有很多时间可以做国之大者。 ■

; Thu, 29 Jun 2023 14:38:40 GMT /内容/l7ghaam1a05u15otgfih4a0bl9c38c38 https://www.economist.com/china/2023/06/29/to-understand-xi-jinping-it-helps-to-be-steeped-in-the-classics A Chinese reality-TV show about farming doubles as propaganda

一名年轻人驾驶着收割机穿过一片稻田。慢点，一位农民责备他。但他继续前进，然后陷入泥沼。欢迎收看《成为农民》，这是爱奇艺（类似 Netflix 的中文服务）上的热门真人秀节目。该剧将十名预科生演员和音乐家从城市移植到浙江省的农村，他们必须在那里生活在一起并尝试务农。

20 多岁的男子（如图）推着巨大的手提箱来到这里，却发现了所谓“不人道”的生活条件：一个露天厕所和无尽的泥浆。当观众解决问题并接受手头的任务时，他们会得到娱乐。 （该组织有六个月的时间从大约十公顷的农田中获利。）但这也是宣传。乡村振兴是中国领导人习近平的宠爱项目。

当然，习近平并不是第一位改善农村生活的中国领导人。 1966-76 年残酷的文化大革命期间，毛泽东将数百万城市居民下放到农村。年轻的习近平就是其中之一。起初他无法忍受，跑回了北京。但他被捕并最终回到了梁家河村。根据共产党的神话，他在那里学到了努力工作的美德。

如今，习近平告诫中国年轻人要表现出“责任感和毅力”——这显然是对他们自身脆弱性的挖苦——并专注于集体目标。 “成为农民”包含了这些信息。 “当你再次见到我时，我将成为一个真正的硬汉，”节目预告片中的一位明星说道。事实上，很快就有人看到他与队友们一起玩耍，互相支持。 “依靠大众总是正确的，”一位人士说道。

食品安全等其他政府优先事项也反映在节目中。剧集提醒观众，中国依赖进口。 “每一粒粮食，每一粒米，都来之不易，”首播中的旁白说道。习近平和其他领导人长期以来一直呼吁中国人的饭碗要用当地种植的农作物。

据政府称，近年来，数百万中国人加入了“新农民”运动。许多人是年轻的毕业生，他们厌倦了激烈的竞争或找不到工作（城市16至24岁的失业率超过20%）。支持新手的国家希望他们的技能能够提高产量。在节目中，明星们滔滔不绝地谈论酷炫的机器和高科技方法。 “我认为农民们很棒，”其中一位说道。

一位制片人今年早些时候表示，该剧旨在重振观众对土壤和自然的热爱。但《成为农民》的政治信息与其植入式广告一样微妙（男人们整天从事体力劳动，但只喝零热量饮料）。习近平表示，年轻人需要“戒骄戒躁”。政府希望他们再次向农民学习。

; Thu, 29 Jun 2023 14:38:40 GMT /内容/rs3vus7f695r05due0etlmmph1c8kcer https://www.economist.com/china/2023/06/29/a-chinese-reality-tv-show-about-farming-doubles-as-propaganda China has its eyes on Okinawa

本月初，当习近平在北京国家档案馆漫步时，这似乎是一次例行巡视。中国最高领导人评论了各种引起他兴趣的物品，例如刻在兽骨上的古代文字和宋代（960-1279）的天文图。但他对明代（1368-1644）手稿的评论最受关注。它描述了中国福建省与独立的琉球王国之间的旧有联系，琉球王国是一系列岛屿，后来被日本吞并并成为冲绳县。一位工作人员表示，这本书“发挥着重要的政治作用”。习近平回应称，他曾在福建担任高级官员，了解两国交往的“深厚”历史。

这看起来似乎不算什么。中国政府从未宣称对琉球群岛拥有主权。但多年来，一批中国学者、分析人士和军事官员一直质疑日本对该岛的统治，其中一些人认为，这些岛屿的居民早在承认日本的权威之前就向中国皇帝进贡。因此，习近平的言论登上了共产党机关报《人民日报》的头版，这很奇怪。一些观察人士认为，此举是为了向日本传达一个信息。

这是十年前第一次“琉球繁荣”期间的想法，一些学者现在称之为“琉球繁荣”。当时，中国和日本就东海五个岛屿发生争执，日本控制这些岛屿并称之为尖阁列岛，但中国声称拥有这些岛屿主权并称之为钓鱼岛。随着紧张局势升级，中国评论员也开始在官方媒体上强调琉球问题。分析人士认为，他们被允许——也许还被鼓励——大肆张扬，以加强中国的讨价还价地位，并向日本表明中国的民族主义情绪很强烈。

如今，琉球出现了新一轮繁荣的迹象。习近平发表上述言论几天后，南方城市深圳的一则官方电视台的报道提出了许多有关这些岛屿的相同问题，并引用了中国专家的话，但他们并没有否认日本对冲绳县的主权。他们谈到了中国在琉球早期历史中所扮演的仁慈角色，并将其与日本欺凌行为的描述进行了对比。

迈阿密大学中国和日本问题专家琼·托菲尔·德雷尔 (June Teufel Dreyer) 看到了一个熟悉的模式。她解释说，当中国想要提出有争议的主张时，可能会首先在一次低调的会议上提及，然后在政府文件或媒体报道中引用，最后由高级官员引用。 “这是一种逐渐造成既成事实的方法，”德雷尔女士说。

就琉球群岛而言，中国评论人士的推论也适用于其他领土争端。日本对尖阁列岛的主权主张部分是基于其声称这些群岛很久以前就由琉球群岛管理的说法。但一些观察人士认为，所有的咆哮实际上都与台湾有关。

去年，日本以对台湾冲突的担忧为由，宣布将增强其在琉球群岛的军事能力，扩大基地并增兵。冲绳岛（属于琉球链的一部分）已经是多个美国军事设施的所在地。中国可能将琉球的繁荣视为表达不满的一种方式。但这不太可能阻止日本加强琉球的防御。恰恰相反。 ■

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 13:46:55 GMT /内容/cpgnofjq5pkr8vjl114d6a8ado8m42su https://www.economist.com/china/2023/06/22/china-has-its-eyes-on-okinawa Why foreign dignitaries wear red when meeting Xi Jinping

洪都拉斯总统希奥马拉·卡斯特罗为本月成功访问北京奠定了基础。今年三月，她的国家断绝了与台湾的关系，转而支持中国。洪都拉斯也正在加入总部位于上海的新开发银行，这是一家由中国共同创办的山寨世界银行。但也许卡斯特罗女士觉得还需要一些额外的东西。当她会见习近平时，她穿着红色裤装和衬衫，系着飘逸的红色领带（如图）。

洪都拉斯总统并不是第一位穿着民族颜色向中国致敬的外国政要。从罗伯特·穆加贝到弗拉基米尔·普京，历任领导人和现任领导人都曾在与习近平会谈时佩戴红色领带。印度总理纳伦德拉·莫迪(Narendra Modi)至少两次在与中国国家主席打招呼时，在尼赫鲁夹克的口袋里塞了一块红手帕。

第一夫人往往走得更远。 1972 年，理查德·尼克松 (Richard Nixon) 的妻子帕特 (Pat) 与总统进行历史性的中国之行时，她身穿红色大衣，定下了基调。 2014 年，米歇尔·奥巴马 (Michelle Obama)（和她的女儿）在北京与习近平会面时，身着深红色连衣裙梅拉尼娅·特朗普2017年访问佛罗里达时也是如此。2018年访问中国时，法国第一夫人布丽吉特·马克龙在一次郊游时穿着大胆的红色外套，在北京参观美术馆时则穿着红色长裙。

对于中国人来说，红色代表着繁荣和吉祥。 14 世纪，明朝开国皇帝朱元璋（红巾起义领袖）宣称它是“最尊贵的颜色”。随着时间的推移，红色与流行习俗联系在一起。中国人会赠送装满现金的红包作为节日礼物。新父母经常收到红鸡蛋来庆祝孩子的诞生。

中国神话讲述了一种叫做“年”的野兽在农历新年开始时吓唬孩子们，直到村民们发现这种怪物被一个穿红衣服的小孩吓跑了。根据这个故事，这就是为什么中国人开始挂红灯笼来庆祝新年和其他节日。

身穿深红色衣服的外国官员可能希望受到习近平的青睐，而不是受到庇护。自法国大革命以来，红色一直是左翼政治的象征，并被共产党所采用。中国的孩子们长期以来被教导说，他们的国旗——红色底色上的五颗金星——代表着“烈士的鲜血”。

对于一些外国政要来说，红色确实带来了幸运。尼克松访问取得成功，标志着中美关系进入了新时代。卡斯特罗女士带着协议离开北京，她希望这些协议能为洪都拉斯带来中国投资。但同样，外国领导人也常常带着一点红色的表情回家时感到失望。与中国的关系往往不仅仅是关系。 ■

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 13:46:55 GMT /内容/jja4ibf38c5lhbhbv9qnv8uids6v9fpv https://www.economist.com/china/2023/06/22/why-foreign-dignitaries-wear-red-when-meeting-xi-jinping When it comes to a war with Taiwan, many Chinese urge caution

很容易激起中国民族主义网民的愤怒，特别是当话题涉及台湾时。任何可能被视为挑战中国对该岛主权主张的行动都会引起人们齐声宣战。他们的声音令西方官员感到震惊，他们担心中国决策者可能会对公众日益高涨的民族主义及其引发的好战情绪做出让步。去年，中国领导人习近平暗示西方的担忧可能是正确的。他警告拜登总统，在台湾问题上，中国公民的观点“不容违抗”。

五年来首位访华的美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯最近访问北京期间会见了习近平，习近平就“稳定中美关系”发表了安抚言论。但在布林肯先生访问的其余时间里，传达的信息是明确的。 “在台湾问题上没有妥协或让步的余地，”中国最高外交官员王毅警告他。外交部长秦刚宣称台湾是双边关系中“最突出的风险”。

中国的许多网络评论员认为，不再值得尝试对台湾采取小手小脚的策略。他们说，“分离主义者”在那里已经根深蒂固。只有战争才能为中国确保这一点。即使习近平同意，他也不会公开表示。在去年十月的一次共产党代表大会上，他表示中国将“继续以最大的诚意、最大的努力争取和平统一”，同时保留“采取一切必要措施的选择”。尽管他表示尊重民意，但他不希望自己的双手被民意束缚。

目前，习近平可能更倾向于谨慎行事。毕竟，与台湾的战争也可能意味着对抗一个拥有核武器的超级大国。他可能还想知道他自己的公众会有多少支持。互联网提供了一个粗略的指南。由于缺乏自由新闻和公开政治辩论可能提供的有用线索，中国官员非常关注网络舆论。他们必须意识到，在社交媒体上要求采取军事行动的呼声中，一些有影响力的网民反对这一想法。 Even among ardent nationalists there are fissures. Some urge caution about going to war, or even argue that fighting may never be necessary: Taiwan will naturally capitulate when it becomes evident that China's power has eclipsed America's.

In a recent paper, Adam Liu of the National University of Singapore and Xiaojun Li of New York University Shanghai argued that support for a near-term war, to the exclusion of all other options, was tiny. Their conclusions were based on a survey they conducted in China between late 2020 and early 2021. Of more than 2,000 respondents, a mere 1% wanted their country to mount a military assault on Taiwan (not just on its outlying islands) before the island's presidential election in January 2024. The ballot will see a new leader elected to replace Tsai Ing-wen, who is retiring and whose centre-left Democratic Progressive Party angers China by stressing Taiwan's separate identity.

Even if China were to decide to go to war by next January, only 55% said that would be acceptable. One-third said it would not be. The authors said their data did not support the idea that demand for the swift mounting of a full-blown attack had grown sharply since Ms Tsai became president in 2016. On the contrary, their survey, taken together with other academics' findings, suggested that “public support for armed unification has remained relatively stable, despite the rapid deterioration in Beijing's relations with both Washington and Taipei,” the scholars wrote.

Their research was conducted before Vladimir Putin launched an all-out invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. Russia's unexpected setbacks in that war, and the West's solidarity in response to it, must have been sobering for some supporters of rapid steps towards wutong , the common shorthand in Chinese for reunification by force (online, to confuse censors, they often use the characters for “parasol tree”, which are also pronounced wutong —though censors usually do not mind calls for war as long as the party and its leaders are not being criticised for failing to act).

Wait, wait

Calls abound for caution about the scale of the task of conquering Taiwan militarily. One such has come from Wu Haipeng, the editor-in-chief of the government's main portal, China.com. Last month Mr Wu wrote on his blog that China had to resolve various “problems” before it could use military means. His proposals for doing so sounded like distant goals. One problem, said Mr Wu, was America's arms supplies to Taiwan and its strengthening of its military posture around the island. To counter this, he suggested, China should beef up its air and rocket forces, as well as its navy—implying that China's military build-up in recent decades has yet to give it the muscle required. He also said China needed to enable its economy to resist sweeping American sanctions that a war would entail. That will not be easy for a country so dependent on global trade.

In January Hu Xijin, a former editor-in-chief of Global Times , a nationalist tabloid, set out three conditions for launching a war. First, China should have at least 1,000 nuclear warheads (the Pentagon believes that it currently has more than 400 and will not achieve Mr Hu's goal until 2030). Second, it should have more missiles and bombs ready for use than do the combined arsenals of America, Japan and Taiwan. Finally, it should be able to launch a rapid, crippling strike against all of Taiwan's military facilities. He said this task would require “far more” munitions per day than the most intense periods of bombardment by America during the wars in Iraq and Kosovo in the 1990s and 2000s. Implicit in his message: much more time is needed.

Like several other prominent nationalists (as opposed to the many who flood social media with short messages like “When are we going to attack? It needs to be quick!”), Mr Wu and Mr Hu do not appear to be braying for war as soon as some in America fear. In a memo in January General Michael Minihan, the head of America's Air Mobility Command, wrote: “My gut tells me we will fight in 2025.” In 2021 Admiral Philip Davidson, then chief of the US Indo-Pacific Command, said: “I think the threat is manifest during this decade, in fact in the next six years.”

Some of China's most radical nationalists (the “parasol-tree faction”, as netizens often call them) have faced fierce criticism online. One of them is Li Yi, a commentator with more than 16,000 followers on Weibo, a Twitter-like service. Last month, in an online video, he said that even if China were to lose 140m people (one-tenth of its population) in a war over Taiwan “it wouldn't be much at all” and that “with a bit of education” young Chinese would all agree that, for the sake of unification, casualties on such a scale would be fine.

The backlash against Mr Li has come from within the nationalist camp as well as from more liberal types. “Which stupid people have given him the cloak of 'patriot'?” said one nationalist blogger with 335,000 followers. Another, with 798,000 followers, asked: “How should we deal with such inhuman, Nazi language?” On June 3rd Huang Jisu—co-author of a book, “Unhappy China”, that became a huge hit among China's nationalists in 2009—gave an online lecture to a neo-Maoist group (a flag-waving lot). Referring to Mr Li's remarks without naming him, he described people who held such views as “fascists”.

Some netizens have even been airing misgivings about going to fight. In April a screenshot of such a post, with its origin unspecified, circulated on Weibo. “If there's a war, I wouldn't go and I wouldn't let my child go,” it said, a few days after China's armed forces staged threatening exercises around Taiwan in response to a meeting in America between Ms Tsai and the speaker of America's House of Representatives, Kevin McCarthy. “I live at the bottom rung of society. No one pays attention to us in peacetime. They only think of us at a time of difficulty,” the message said. Nationalists responded with outrage. “This kind of person will always be at the bottom, their thinking is at the bottom…” wrote one to his nearly 4.2m followers. But among hundreds who responded to his invective, some took issue. “I won't go. Let the children of leading cadres go first, they have good red genes,” said one. Officials may be weighing up such words. ■

; Mon, 19 Jun 2023 18:08:24 GMT /content/nfvmv86m6l84vi9tbhfkk5h379vku96a https://www.economist.com/china/2023/06/19/when-it-comes-to-a-war-with-taiwan-many-chinese-urge-caution China hopes Mazu, a sea goddess, can help it win over Taiwan

T he sleepy town of Yuanlin in central Taiwan is transformed when Mazu passes through. The maiden-turned-goddess lived in southern China during the tenth century—and, according to legend, used her mystical powers to save relatives from a shipwreck. Despite her roots in the mainland, she is widely worshipped in Taiwan. Each year her statue is carried across the island on a multi-day tour. In Yuanlin she was greeted by firecrackers and prostrate devotees. One woman burst into tears. Mazu healed her from cancer and protected her from covid-19, she says.

Officials in Beijing hope Mazu will help them in a different way. The United Front Work Department, the Communist Party branch with the job of boosting China's influence abroad, views the goddess as a tool to win Taiwanese hearts and minds.

Mazu—or Lin Moniang, as she was known before becoming a goddess—hailed from a small fishing village on the island of Meizhou in the province of Fujian. Today worshippers make pilgrimages to her ancestral temple there. That is useful to China, which has been supporting Mazu-related cultural exchanges with Taiwan since the late 1990s. Local offices of the United Front talk openly of using Mazu to “strengthen Taiwan's patriotic unification force”. If they can turn Taiwan's love of Mazu into love of the motherland, that would make it easier to peacefully bring Taiwan back under the mainland's rule.

In recent years China has taken a hardline approach to Taiwan, buzzing its airspace with military jets and performing drills around the island. But with covid restrictions lifted and a Taiwanese presidential election scheduled for next year, China's influence operations are increasing. In February the head of the Taiwan Mazu Fellowship, a large network of temples, met Song Tao, the head of China's Taiwan Affairs Office in Beijing. They discussed how Mazu could play a role in promoting “one family” on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, according to Chinese state media.

At Tai'an Gong, a small temple in Taipei that belongs to the Taiwan Mazu Fellowship, two elders proudly point to a gilded plaque that they received from the Meizhou temple. Every time representatives of Tai'an Gong visit, they are feted with banquets, says one of the elders. The leaders of each temple are “like brothers”, he says. In some cases they are also business partners.

The head of the temple in Meizhou is a member of China's People's Political Consultative Conference, a government advisory body. But the cultural exchanges are “not political”, insists Ah Sen, a director at Tai'an Gong. He points to calendars on the wall from different temple associations in Taiwan, some of which favour unification, whereas others back independence. Those who take part in the trips to Meizhou already lean a certain way, so they will not change their minds, he says. And at Tai'an Gong it does not matter which party worshippers support; everyone comes for Mazu. The two elders agree, sharing stories of how the goddess saved them from car accidents and stockmarket crashes.

It is difficult to assess the impact of China's Mazu-related efforts. Many factors influence how a Taiwanese person votes and what they think about China. The views of temple leaders are not that important, says Ku Ming-chun, a sociologist at Taiwan's National Tsing Hua University. Worshippers do not feel a need to be politically aligned with them. But China uses the cultural exchanges to sow disinformation. Delegations of Taiwanese pilgrims often form chat groups that become platforms for Chinese propaganda, says Ms Ku.

Chang Kuei-min of National Taiwan University says China has created a narrative in which the Communist Party is a champion of folk religion, while Taiwan's government opposes it. Before Ms Chang went on a religious exchange to China in 2019, a temple elder warned her that she might be questioned by Taiwan's security services on her return. She saw this as a regurgitation of Chinese propaganda. In Beijing, she says, officials spoke of how Taiwan's government was politicising religion. “Surely Mazu is not an agent of the Communist Party?” they would say, according to Ms Chang. Of course, that is exactly what the party wants Mazu to be. ■

; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 13:20:26 GMT /content/th02nt8rrutj68dss9gag1halegoac7o https://www.economist.com/china/2023/06/15/china-hopes-mazu-a-sea-goddess-can-help-it-win-over-taiwan China’s tolerance for public oversight is limited

P ublic displays of affection can have dire consequences in China. Just ask Hu Jiyong. The boss (and Communist Party secretary) of the subsidiary of a state-owned firm held hands with a female subordinate as they strolled through Chengdu this month. Her pink dress caught the attention of a fashion photographer, who posted a video of the couple online. A commenter recognised Mr Hu and said that he was married to another woman.

Having a mistress is often seen as a sign of official corruption in China. So netizens launched what is known as a “human-flesh search”—a kind of crowdsourced investigation. They dug up photos that suggested the woman was spending lavishly. A formal investigation of Mr Hu was launched by anti-corruption authorities (no proof has yet emerged of wrongdoing). Both he and his companion have been suspended from their jobs. Adultery, while not illegal in China, is against party rules.

Some joke that the authorities should rely more on street photographers. Such humour highlights the party's complicated relationship with individuals and groups that expose wrongdoing. Officials are supposed to submit to the “democratic supervision” of the people. Citizens have long helped to reveal misdeeds. In one rather infamous case, in 2008, footage emerged of a man in a hotel arguing with a couple who had accused him of assaulting their daughter. “I rank as high as your mayor. How dare you quarrel with me,” he said. After online sleuths worked out his name and party rank, he was fired.

When it comes to adultery, sometimes little investigation is needed. In the 2010s a string of officials were brought down by scorned mistresses who took to social media. One, called Ji Yingnan, posted details of her luxurious lifestyle after discovering that her lover, an official at the National Archives Administration, was married.

But the party's tolerance for public supervision is limited. In 2014 the authorities accused members of the “New Citizens' Movement” of organising protests featuring banners that urged officials to declare their assets. Three of the activists were given prison sentences. In 2017 a commentary in the People's Daily , a party mouthpiece, warned that online corruption investigations could threaten social stability by stirring up resentment of officials and the rich. “The government must guide people's emotions…to create a rational, peaceful and positive public opinion,” it argued.

The party's reaction seems to depend in part on the rank of the alleged offender and, thus, the risk to its reputation. In 2021 Peng Shuai, a professional tennis player, revealed on social media that she had been in a years-long extramarital affair with Zhang Gaoli, a former member of the Politburo Standing Committee, the party's top leaders. She accused him of sexual assault. Censors quickly scrubbed her post from the internet and Ms Peng disappeared for two weeks. After re-emerging, she denied she had made the accusation.

Things have gone differently in Mr Hu's case. Under the law, human-flesh searches are banned. Officials criticise them for violating privacy and leading to cyber-bullying. (Mr Hu's companion has been the target of online attacks.) But the party seems to think that the furore surrounding the executive is manageable—and perhaps even useful if it helps deter such behaviour. ■

; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 13:20:26 GMT /content/9vme759ck1bnuo751jhcgufsfnoc63a4 https://www.economist.com/china/2023/06/15/chinas-tolerance-for-public-oversight-is-limited Xi Jinping reaches into China’s ancient history for a new claim to rule

F or decades outsiders have told a simple story about the ties that bind China's Communist Party and its people. This story describes a bargain between rulers and subjects, in rather condescending terms. In this telling, most Chinese people, from the toiling masses to the urban middle classes, know to avoid talking or thinking about politics. And in exchange for shunning the world of power, citizens are allowed to compete for their share of the wealth and opportunities generated by a rising China. Recently—as China's economy slows, house prices slide and job opportunities for new graduates dwindle—the same outsiders have taken to wondering whether the public might turn on the party.

In fact, that economically focused description of China's social compact understates the party's ambitions, certainly since Xi Jinping took over as supreme leader 11 years ago. Mr Xi has for some time played down the pursuit of material wealth as a national cause and put politics—albeit in a strictly policed, top-down form—back at the centre of daily life. He has enjoyed considerable success, at least to date. A striking number of citizens—and especially those born after 1990, who have known only ever-growing national wealth and strength—have been ready to believe that, on balance, China succeeds because of its stern, one-party political system, not despite it.

When unelected governments or autocracies claim that they deserve to rule because they govern well and efficiently, political scientists talk of appeals to “performance legitimacy”. In this vein, the first two years of the covid-19 pandemic were a particular gift to party ideologues. Day after day, the propaganda machine pumped out news of the latest covid death toll in America, backed by images of patients on ventilators in Western hospitals, recycled clips of President Donald Trump scorning science at White House press conferences, and protests in Western cities against lockdowns, mask-wearing and vaccine mandates. For sure, censorship was heavy and omnipresent, and locked-down Chinese chafed against thuggish enforcement of zero-covid rules, especially as the pandemic dragged on. On balance, though, boasts of Chinese exceptionalism rang true for many citizens. Party ideologues hailed Mr Xi as commander-in-chief of a people's war against covid, offering China order and safety, in contrast with squabbling, selfish, Western democracies.

Alongside boasts about the party's governing competence, Mr Xi has offered darker calls for China to become self-reliant and learn to struggle against foreign foes. In speeches he talks of China's re-emergence as a great power, and how that will involve defying a hostile American-led West bent on containment. Such talk of dangers serves more than one purpose. It unifies the masses, while turning anyone with conflicting views into an enemy within. For in times of peril, dissent by underlings is a form of sabotage, like a sailor arguing with the captain of a storm-tossed ship.

Yet a mandate to rule based on the claim that the party is exceptionally competent, and indeed is successful because it brooks no dissent, becomes a trap when top leaders mess up. A decisive, though tyrannical, captain quickly becomes a liability if he repeatedly steers the ship of state onto rocks. An unusually candid essay by two Chinese scholars, Fu Yu and Gui Yong, describes a crisis of confidence among the young. The work, based in part on surveys of social media, is flagged and translated by David Ownby of the University of Montreal on his “Reading the China Dream” blog.

Focusing on Chinese born after the 1990s, it describes a gap between their patriotism and high expectations of their rulers, and the realities of a society that seems to them cruelly unequal, to the point that hard-working provincial Chinese can never catch up with those born into privilege. First published in 2022 and reissued last month by an academic journal, the Beijing Cultural Review , the essay, “The Five Intriguing Paradoxes of Contemporary Chinese Young People”, describes youngsters who have turned against “evil” private capital and want a strong state to tame it. Some are suffering “crises of belief” that are leading many to shun marriage and decline to have children. Worse, since the piece was first published, the country has endured the sudden, bungled collapse of its zero-covid policy and the concealment of large numbers of deaths, further undermining public confidence.

A new pitch, for a slower-growing China

Not unrelatedly perhaps, on June 2nd Mr Xi outlined his broadest-yet claim to rule, based on China's exceptional culture. He called China the only civilisation to be uninterrupted over many millennia. As if suggesting that convergence with liberal values would betray every dynasty that preceded him, Mr Xi declared: “The fact that Chinese civilisation is highly consistent is the fundamental reason why the Chinese nation must follow its own path.” Because Chinese civilisation is unusually uniform, Mr Xi went on, different ethnic groups must be integrated and the nation unified: code for imposing Chinese culture on Tibet and other regions, and for taking back Taiwan. For anyone puzzled that a once-revolutionary party now calls itself the “faithful inheritor” of “excellent traditional culture” (plus a dose of Marxism), the People's Daily weighed in with commentaries explaining why Mr Xi's emphasis on cultural confidence is vital in a perilous moment when “strategic opportunities, risks and challenges co-exist”. Economic heft is not enough, the newspaper added. If China's economy develops but its spirit is lost, “Can the country be called strong?”

Take a step back, and Mr Xi is crafting an appeal to what might be termed civilisational legitimacy. When the public is disappointed by a slowing economy and by the pandemic's incompetent ending, this gambit must be tempting. After all, who will dare challenge a mandate to rule that is supposedly unchanged in 5,000 years? How foreign governments are supposed to engage with such chauvinism is a different and worrying question. ■

; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 13:20:26 GMT /content/elclbbt6en75qvrruraonftm9fcqtfmh https://www.economist.com/china/2023/06/15/xi-jinping-reaches-into-chinas-ancient-history-for-a-new-claim-to-rule America and China try to move past a new bump in relations

F ew Americans would ever forget those chilling 18 minutes in the evening of October 22nd 1962. As they gathered around their radios and televisions, their president, John F. Kennedy, revealed that the Soviet Union had moved nuclear-capable missiles to Cuba, 90 miles (140km) from the coast of Florida. America would blockade the island until they were removed, he said. It was the first the public learned of the crisis that over the next five days would bring the world to the brink of nuclear war.

Analogies with that episode were perhaps inevitable when the Wall Street Journal , followed by several other American media outlets, reported on June 8th that China had made a secret agreement to establish a listening station in Cuba. Senators from both sides of the aisle urged the White House to take preventative action. Mike Gallagher, a Republican congressman who chairs the House of Representatives' new bipartisan Select Committee on the Chinese Communist Party, warned that a new cold war “once again, has come to our doorstep”. He even quoted from Kennedy's address that night in 1962.

Yet such comparisons are undue. The White House, having initially dismissed the reports as inaccurate, now says that China has gathered signals intelligence from Cuba for some time and upgraded its facilities there in 2019. Officials say they have shared their concerns with Cuba and successfully lobbied other governments not to host Chinese military or spying outposts. Despite the furore, America's secretary of state, Antony Blinken (pictured), will go ahead with a long-delayed visit to Beijing—his first in that role—on June 18th.

Chinese eavesdropping in Cuba is, indeed, nothing new. A report from the US Army War College's Strategic Studies Institute in 2011 suggested that China had access to three listening stations there, at Bejucal, Santiago de Cuba and Lourdes. It was using them to intercept radio and mobile-phone transmissions, and to conduct cyber-espionage, the report said. The Lourdes facility, just outside Havana, was the Soviet Union's biggest overseas listening station and used by Russia until the early 2000s.

Dennis Wilder, a former China analyst at the CIA and now a professor at Georgetown University, says he had been aware of China's use of Cuba for electronic eavesdropping since the end of the cold war. The facilities there, he says, are most likely operated by the Third Department of the People's Liberation Army Joint Staff Department (often referred to as 3 PLA and roughly equivalent to America's National Security Agency). Other 3 PLA sites may include North Korea, Pakistan and Djibouti, where China opened its first (and only) overseas military base in 2017.

China is probably using facilities in Cuba to try to hoover up information related to American satellite systems, Mr Wilder suggests, and the recent upgrades may have involved installing bigger, more powerful data-gathering equipment, which is often contained in large round structures known as radomes. “That's the kind of thing that I think that the Chinese are trying to put in Cuba—very large arrays with tremendous capability,” he says. “That kind of capability would be very, very useful to the Chinese military.”

Troubling as that may be for America, it has few good options to respond. China and Cuba have both denied the media reports and the Biden administration's subsequent allegations. Anyway, such facilities do not violate international law. And America is thought to have many similar sites in countries around the world, including Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and Australia, and uses them to gather signals intelligence on China. So America is unlikely seriously to escalate its protests over any such Chinese activity in Cuba.

China, meanwhile, is using the controversy to highlight what it sees as American hypocrisy. “Slanders and smears” would not obscure America's “deplorable track record of indiscriminate mass spying around the world”, a foreign-ministry spokesman said on June 12th. In a call with Mr Blinken two days later, Qin Gang, China's foreign minister (pictured), rebuked America for harming China's security. But both sides have confirmed Mr Blinken's trip. And though American officials do not expect breakthroughs on a lengthy agenda, including Taiwan and Ukraine, they hope the visit will help to establish better lines of communication. “Intense competition requires intense diplomacy,” said one.

That will come as a relief to many other countries, especially in Asia. They worried that tensions were spiralling out of control in February when America shot down a Chinese high-altitude balloon that the Pentagon said had been monitoring American military bases. China said the balloon was gathering meteorological data, but the White House rejected that explanation and postponed a visit by Mr Blinken that had been scheduled for later that month.

The effect was to stall efforts to stabilise relations that President Joe Biden and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, began when they met in Bali in November. In the past few weeks, however, there has been a swirl of high-level contacts, including a visit to Beijing in May by William Burns, the CIA chief. Jake Sullivan, America's national-security adviser, also met Wang Yi, China's top diplomat, in Vienna that month. Economic officials have met, too.

Resuming high-level talks is important because it means the two sides can at least communicate their positions in private. That is preferable to doing so in heated public exchanges as they have for much of the time since a visit to Taiwan in August by Nancy Pelosi, then the speaker of America's House of Representatives. Direct contacts could also facilitate progress on some technical and commercial issues, which would smooth the way for Mr Xi's expected attendance of the Asia-Pacific Economic Co-operation forum in San Francisco in November. Mr Blinken's trip could open the door, too, for others whom China is more interested in receiving, such as America's treasury secretary, Janet Yellen, and climate envoy, John Kerry.

Even so, the Cuba controversy is a reminder that high-level strategic tensions endure—and will not be easily resolved. That was also clear when China's defence minister, Li Shangfu, refused to hold talks with America's defence secretary, Lloyd Austin, at a security conference in Singapore in early June (China wants American sanctions on General Li lifted first). In their public statements, General Li warned America and its allies to stop surveillance operations near China's coast, while Mr Austin cited an “alarming increase” in unsafe Chinese intercepts of American and allied ships and aircraft.

The Cuban contretemps also feeds into a domestic political climate in both China and America that is making it harder for their leaders to compromise on any substantial issues. And their room for manoeuvre could shrink further in the coming months, with a presidential election due in Taiwan in January and campaigning for America's presidential poll expected to start in earnest this August with the first Republican primary debate.

The level of hostility towards China on both sides of the aisle in Congress was writ large in responses to the Cuba reports. “We urge the Biden administration to take steps to prevent this serious threat to our national security and sovereignty,” said Mark Warner, the Democrat who chairs the Senate Intelligence Committee, and Marco Rubio, the Republican vice-chairman. Mr Gallagher accused the Biden administration of whitewashing Chinese aggression. “We must make it clear that, as President Kennedy said over 60 years ago on the eve of a previous crisis in Cuba, 'One path we shall never choose, and that is the path of surrender or submission.'” ■
